job_description: PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT ENGINEER Co-OpDivision: Communication Products DivisionLocation: Saskatoon, SkAPPLY WITH RESUME AND TRANSCRIPT TO JOB #1089715004As a Product Development Engineer Co-Op, you will join a  team of professionals in developing exciting, leading edge integrated circuits for high speed optical networks.  Reporting to the Leader,  Product Development, your responsibilities may include, but are not limited to the following:• Assist in many aspects of advanced CMOS device design and verification.• Responsibilities may include circuit and system design, testbench design, coding, simulation test case execution and assistance in debugging VHDL and/or Verilog module designs.• Assist with formal verification, design for testability, and static timing analysis.• Assist with the functional  verification of new and innovative digital System-on-chip (SoC) devices and subsystems.• Work in a dynamic team environment to ensure common project goals are accomplished.• Analyze requirements and specifications to develop resource estimates and verification plans. • Learn and understand applicable communication protocol standards.• Develop scripts to automate tasks
job_requirements: Qualifications• Electrical Engineering or Computer Engineering student in their 3rd or 4th year.• Previous relevant co-op or full-time experience is desirable.• Experience with structured programming, HDLs such as VHDL or Verilog is essential• Proficiency with Linux/UNIX is required.• Excellent analytical, communication and documentation skills• Good design and troubleshooting skills• Self-starter with a passion to deliver high quality, high performance firmwareDESIRABLE QUALIFICATIONS•  Familiarity with transmission formats such as Ethernet, TCP/IP, OTN  is desirable.• Experience with embedded programming of CPUs is an asset.• Familiarity with Perl and/or TCL, and OOP is an asset.•  Familiar with a structured professional coding environment: participating in code reviews, following standard revision control, bug tracking, and release practicesOpen To All Majors:No
